conclusion: To determine the pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K, we need to analyze the given graphs and use the ideal gas law.
The ideal gas law is PV = nRT, where P is the pressure, V is the volume, n is the number of moles, R is the ideal gas constant, and T is the temperature in Kelvin.
The p-T graph shows the relationship between pressure and temperature.
The relationship between pressure and temperature for an ideal gas at constant volume is linear, as given by P/T = constant.
Calculate the slope of the line in the p-T graph: slope = (1.0 - 0.5) x 10^5 Pa / (400 K - 200 K) = 2.5 x 10^2 Pa/K.
Use the slope to find the pressure at 600 K using P = P0 + slope x (T - T0).
Here, P0 = 0.5 x 10^5 Pa at T0 = 200 K.
Substitute the values: P = 0.5 x 10^5 Pa + 2.5 x 10^2 Pa/K x (600 K - 200 K).
Calculate: P = 0.5 x 10^5 Pa + 2.5 x 10^2 Pa/K x 400 K.
Calculate: P = 0.5 x 10^5 Pa + 1.0 x 10^5 Pa.
The pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K is 1.5 x 10^5 Pa.
This solution assumes that the volume remains constant between the points given in the p-T graph, which is consistent with the behavior of an ideal gas under constant volume conditions.
